question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective way to control problematic plants on peatlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on cost-effectiveness is not reported, but studies on effectiveness include: Herbicide application in fens changed overall plant community composition, did not prevent increases in shrub cover over time, and prevented increases in total plant species richness (1776). Using covers or barriers to control problematic plants has no identified studies on peatland vegetation (1775). Physically damaging problematic plants has no identified studies on peatland vegetation (1769). Grazing to control problematic plants has no identified studies on peatland vegetation (1773). Cutting/removing problematic large trees/shrubs in fens changed plant community composition toward more open-fen characteristics; in Sweden it increased richness and cover of fen-characteristic plants and increased moss and vascular plant cover, whereas a replicated USA study reported shrub cover still increased over time and total plant species richness increases were prevented (1772). Cutting/mowing problematic herbaceous plants showed mixed outcomes: two Swedish rich-fen studies found no significant effect on overall community composition, a UK fen meadow study found mown plots developed different communities; one Swedish study found more fen-characteristic species in mown plots (without higher cover); cover responses varied by species, and clipping did not affect Sphagnum growth in an Estonian bog (1770). Physical removal of problematic plants in fens increased cover of fen-characteristic plants in one study, had mixed effects on herb cover, often reduced bryophyte and Sphagnum cover (especially in drained plots), and increased plant species richness only in a drained area (1768).
summary_statements: Evidence on cost-effectiveness for controlling problematic plants on peatlands is not reported.
Herbicide application in fens changed overall plant community composition.
Herbicide application in fens did not prevent increases in shrub cover over time.
Herbicide application in fens prevented increases in total plant species richness.
There are no identified studies on peatland vegetation regarding the use of covers or barriers to control problematic plants.
There are no identified studies on peatland vegetation regarding physically damaging problematic plants.
There are no identified studies on peatland vegetation regarding the use of grazing to control problematic plants.
Cutting or removing problematic large trees and shrubs in fens changed the plant community composition toward more open-fen characteristics.
In Sweden, cutting or removing problematic large trees and shrubs increased the richness and cover of fen-characteristic plants.
In Sweden, cutting or removing problematic large trees and shrubs increased moss and vascular plant cover.
A replicated USA study reported that despite cutting or removing problematic large trees and shrubs, shrub cover still increased over time.
A replicated USA study reported that cutting or removing problematic large trees and shrubs prevented increases in total plant species richness.
Cutting or mowing problematic herbaceous plants showed mixed outcomes.
Two Swedish rich-fen studies found no significant effect on overall community composition from cutting or mowing problematic herbaceous plants.
A UK fen meadow study found mown plots developed different communities from unmown plots.
One Swedish study found more fen-characteristic species in mown plots, but not a higher cover of those species.
When cutting or mowing problematic herbaceous plants, plant cover responses varied by species.
In an Estonian bog, clipping problematic plants did not affect Sphagnum growth.
The physical removal of problematic plants in fens increased the cover of fen-characteristic plants in one study.
The physical removal of problematic plants in fens had mixed effects on herb cover.
The physical removal of problematic plants in fens often reduced bryophyte and Sphagnum cover, especially in drained plots.
The physical removal of problematic plants in fens increased plant species richness only in a drained area.
